metadata.title: নলেন গুড় তৈরির পদ্ধতি |Nalen Gur| Rural Recipes | #villagefood #villagefoodtour #villagefoodsecrets
metadata.description:
পূর্ব বর্ধমান জেলার আউশগ্রামের বাসিন্দা জামাল মণ্ডল | রুরাল রেসিপি-র উনচল্লিশ তম পর্ব |
Nalen Gur by Jamal Mondal from Aushgram, Purba Bardhaman.

Rural local recipes are integral part of Intangible Cultural Heritage and needs to be preserved and promoted. We at banglanatak dot com have been working for the past 22+ years to safeguard and promote local cultural heritages in rural spaces across India.  We are now launching a new initiative of documenting rural recipes and bringing them closer to the food lovers of the world.  We request all to subscribe to our new channel Rural Recipes and stay tuned there to know, learn and try out local delicacies.

Presenter: Jamil Akhtar
ingredients_detected: Khejur Rosh (Date palm sap/juice) - collected fresh from trees

transcription_bengali: [00:00:46.000] উনি গুড়ের ব্যবসায়ী—শিউলি/শিউলি (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্ট অনুযায়ী শব্দ অস্পষ্ট)।
[00:00:52.000] আপনাদের দেখাব নলেন গুড় কীভাবে বানানো হয়।
[00:01:33.000] আমি ভোর ৪টেয় (বাগান/গাছে) যাই। (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে ‘hospital’ এসেছে, সম্ভবত ভুল)
[00:01:57.000] গাছগুলো কীভাবে মেইনটেন করেন—বললে ভালো হয়।
[00:02:40.000] এটা আমরা অপেক্ষা না করেই করে দিয়েছি। (বাক্য অস্পষ্ট)
[00:02:46.000] আমরা এখান থেকে রস নামানোর চেষ্টা করি,
[00:03:15.000] আপনি সকালে ভ্যান নিয়ে বের হন, তাই তো?
[00:05:00.000] আগুন ঠিকমতো জ্বলবে না। (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে বাক্য অস্পষ্ট)
[00:05:20.000] ওঠানামা করলে মরতে হবে। (অর্থ অস্পষ্ট/ভুল অনুবাদ হতে পারে)
[00:05:28.000] পশ্চিমবঙ্গ ও বাংলাদেশে গুড়ের ইতিহাস খুব পুরনো।
[00:06:13.000] দেড় ঘণ্টা জ্বাল দেওয়ার পর আমরা এই অবস্থায় এসেছি।
[00:07:14.000] নলেন গুড় নাম নিয়ে অনেক গল্প/মিথ আছে।
[00:08:00.000] ২ ঘণ্টা ৪০ মিনিট পরে আমরা (মাহেন্দ্র ক্ষণ/মাহেন্দ্রখান) পর্যায়ে এসেছি। (লাইন অস্পষ্ট)
[00:08:21.000] আমরা ‘নামিল’/‘নামিল’ ব্যবহার করছি, তাই তো? (শব্দ অস্পষ্ট)
[00:09:29.000] আপনার গ্রাম/কমিউনিটিতে কোনো ইউনিক রেসিপি থাকলে,
[00:09:37.000] আমরা সেটা আপনাদের সামনে আনার চেষ্টা করব।
transcription_english: [00:00:15.000] In this winter, we have stepped out.
[00:00:19.000] This is not a veg recipe or a non-veg recipe.
[00:00:23.000] This is a signature item of Bengal.
[00:00:37.000] Can you guess where I am?
[00:00:40.000] I have come in search of nolen gur.
[00:00:44.000] I have come to Jamal-bhai’s house.
[00:00:46.000] He is a gur maker/businessman—(word unclear in transcript).
[00:00:49.000] And he has a lot of trees.
[00:00:52.000] I will show you how nolen gur is made.
[00:00:54.000] I will show you the whole process.
[00:01:03.000] I have come here early in the morning.
[00:01:05.000] Will you drink date palm sap?
[00:01:11.000] Come, hold my hand / I’ll take you.
[00:01:31.000] Where do you collect the sap from?
[00:01:33.000] I go out at 4 in the morning. (Transcript said “hospital”, likely wrong.)
[00:01:39.000] You collect sap from the trees at 4 a.m.?
[00:01:41.000] And I collect it again at 6 in the evening.
[00:01:57.000] It would be good if you tell us how you maintain the trees.
[00:02:02.000] Let’s see the trees in the garden.
[00:02:04.000] There are many date palm trees all around.
[00:02:07.000] Do you maintain all the trees,
[00:02:10.000] How many trees are there in total?
[00:02:13.000] For how many months does it run?
[00:02:16.000] We start pruning the trees from the eighth month.
[00:02:21.000] After pruning, do you get sap immediately?
[00:02:24.000] How long do you have to wait?
[00:02:40.000] we did this without waiting (line unclear).
[00:02:42.000] If you leave it for 3 more hours,
[00:02:44.000] then it will start flowing/dripping (line unclear).
[00:02:46.000] we try to collect sap from here,
[00:02:55.000] It is a very difficult task,
[00:02:58.000] and we have to work very hard for it.
[00:03:03.000] We sit in Kolkata or the city,
[00:03:15.000] You leave in the morning with vans, right?
[00:03:18.000] We go out in four vans.
[00:03:20.000] We collect sap from the trees
[00:03:44.000] It’s a lot of hard work.
[00:03:59.000] Now I will light the fire.
[00:04:11.000] It will boil? Yes, it will boil.
[00:04:26.000] There are some other numbers too (unclear).
[00:04:27.000] After burning for half an hour,
[00:04:30.000] a lot of smoke has come out.
[00:04:32.000] Now I will let the smoke out.
[00:04:46.000] What do you call this place?
[00:04:54.000] So does it get smoky/dim here often?
[00:04:57.000] The smoke exits from this side.
[00:05:00.000] the fire won’t burn properly (line unclear).
[00:05:01.000] If it gets dark, nothing will be visible.
[00:05:03.000] That’s why the firewood is kept over there.
[00:05:04.000] So the firewood is kept here?
[00:05:06.000] Okay, so it won’t get wet.
[00:05:12.000] Will there be smoke all the time?
[00:05:17.000] Water is coming out through the bamboo (unclear).
[00:05:20.000] going up and down becomes dangerous (meaning unclear).
[00:05:23.000] Like this, it is about five feet.
[00:05:28.000] In West Bengal and Bangladesh, the history of gur is very old.
[00:05:32.000] There are references to it in historical sources.
[00:05:36.000] But the exact place of origin
[00:05:40.000] Some say it began in North 24 Parganas,
[00:05:43.000] and many say the word “gur” comes from “Gaur”.
[00:05:48.000] Some say Bengal, some say Gaur—
[00:06:00.000] It is a signature element of Bengali culture.
[00:06:05.000] In our taste and food culture.
[00:06:13.000] After 1.5 hours of boiling, we have reached this stage.
[00:06:28.000] The color has changed a lot.
[00:06:32.000] The volume has reduced a lot too.
[00:06:35.000] How much longer will it take?
[00:06:38.000] It will take another half an hour.
[00:06:41.000] You will add green chilies again.
[00:06:43.000] What will you do with the chilies?
[00:06:52.000] It is a very labor-intensive process.
[00:06:59.000] The color has changed a lot.
[00:07:02.000] There will be one more stage.
[00:07:03.000] There will be one more stage.
[00:07:14.000] There are many myths about the name “nolen gur”.
[00:07:29.000] when a “nol” is cut, the sap that comes out,
[00:07:32.000] is the source of the word “nolen”.
[00:07:39.000] “nolen” comes from cutting the “nol” and extracting sap.
[00:07:45.000] That is where the name “nolen” comes from.
[00:08:00.000] After 2 hours and 40 minutes, we have reached the final stage (line unclear).
[00:08:05.000] I’ll ask Rupam to show us.
[00:08:30.000] How long will it take to cool down?
[00:08:34.000] The more it cools, the thicker it becomes.
[00:08:55.000] It has cooled for about an hour.
[00:08:57.000] It will cool a bit more.
[00:09:11.000] So viewers, we’re saying goodbye here today.
[00:09:29.000] if you have any unique recipe in your village or community,
[00:09:37.000] We will try to bring it to everyone.
